fields.name: Title
fields.description: Full title of the study as stated in the paper
fields.value: Applying Large Language Models for Causal Structure Learning in Non Small Cell Lung Cancer
fields.evidence_quote: "Applying Large Language Models for Causal Structure Learning in Non Small Cell Lung Cancer"

fields.name: Author(s)
fields.description: List of all authors involved in the paper, in order of appearance
fields.value: Narmada Naik, Ayush Khandelwal, Mohit Joshi, Madhusudan Atre, Hollis Wright, Kavya Kannan, Scott Hill, Giridhar Mamidipudi, Ganapati Srinivasa, Carlo Bifulco, Brian Piening, Kevin Matlock
fields.evidence_quote: "Narmada Naik¹, Ayush Khandelwal¹, Mohit Joshi¹, Madhusudan Atre¹, Hollis Wright¹, Kavya Kannan¹, Scott Hill¹, Giridhar Mamidipudi¹, Ganapati Srinivasa¹, Carlo Bifulco², Brian Piening2, Kevin Matlock¹"

fields.name: Patient Co-authors
fields.description: Were any co-authors identified as patients or caregivers?

fields.name: Journal
fields.description: Name of the journal where the study was published

fields.name: Publication Stage
fields.description: Indicate if the paper is peer-reviewed, a preprint, or another stage

fields.name: Publication Date
fields.description: Official date the paper was published

fields.name: Field of Study
fields.description: Disciplinary or clinical field, such as primary care, oncology, or public health
fields.evidence_quote: "In this article, we focus on incorporating the feedback of LLM for CSL in the medical domain, specifically the field of oncology"

fields.name: Country
fields.description: Country or countries where the study was conducted or primarily situated
fields.evidence_quote: "¹dātma Health Science, Beaverton, OR, USA, ²Earle A. Chiles Research Institute, Providence Cancer Institute, Portland, OR, USA"

fields.name: Type of Article
fields.description: Classify the article: original research, protocol, review, commentary, etc.

fields.name: Aim of Study
fields.description: State the main purpose or objective of the study as described by the authors
fields.value: To investigate applying Large Language Models (LLMs) to determine the directionality of edges in causal discovery for Non Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) patients.
fields.evidence_quote: "In this paper we investigate applying LLMs to the problem of determining the directionality of edges in causal discovery. Specifically, we test our approach on a deidentified set of Non Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) patients that have both electronic health record and genomic panel data."

fields.name: Key Findings
fields.description: Summarize the main results or conclusions of the study
fields.value: LLMs can accurately predict the directionality of edges in causal graphs, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods.
fields.evidence_quote: "Our result shows that LLMs can accurately predict the directionality of edges in causal graphs, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods."

fields.name: Patient/Public Engagement (Y/N)
fields.description: Does the study report any meaningful or intentional involvement of patients or the public in any phase of the research or implementation?
fields.evidence_quote: "Afterwards, we started updating the model using human intervention. We first corrected the lack of Age influencing smoking status of a patient with the following prompt, "how age is not cause smoking please relook into the adjacency matrix and generate a correct one." Then we add in that staging and smoking should be effecting the mutation status, “the stage group and smoking should cause some mutation in nsclc." This represents the V3 LLM DAG."

fields.name: Type of Engagement (Montreal Model continuum)
fields.description: Categorize engagement based on the Montreal Model: Information (e.g., newsletters), Consultation (e.g., surveys, focus groups), Collaboration (e.g., co-design sessions), or Partnership (e.g., decision-making roles, advisory boards).
fields.value: Consultation - Human intervention to correct and update the model.
fields.evidence_quote: "Afterwards, we started updating the model using human intervention. We first corrected the lack of Age influencing smoking status of a patient with the following prompt, "how age is not cause smoking please relook into the adjacency matrix and generate a correct one." Then we add in that staging and smoking should be effecting the mutation status, “the stage group and smoking should cause some mutation in nsclc." This represents the V3 LLM DAG."

fields.name: Level of Patient Involvement (Montreal Model)
fields.description: At what level were patients or the public involved across the research lifecycle? Score each phase (design, development, evaluation, implementation) as: None, Information, Consultation, Collaboration, or Partnership.
fields.value: Design: None, Development: Consultation, Evaluation: None, Implementation: None

fields.name: Evaluation of Impact (Y/N)
fields.description: Did the study evaluate or measure the effect of patient/public engagement?

fields.name: Type of Evaluation
fields.description: What type of method or framework was used to evaluate the impact of engagement (e.g., metrics, qualitative feedback, evaluation framework)?

fields.name: Impact of Engagement
fields.description: Describe any outcomes or changes attributed to patient/public engagement (e.g., design changes, improved recruitment, insights).

fields.name: Participatory Process
fields.description: Did the study include a participatory design process such as workshops, co-design, or stakeholder sessions?
fields.value: Yes - Human intervention to correct and update the model.

fields.name: Continuous Evaluation Cycles
fields.description: Was engagement conducted iteratively or cyclically, with feedback loops or repeated interaction?

fields.name: Implementation
fields.description: Did patient/public engagement influence the implementation strategy or process of the research?

fields.name: Organization of Health Care
fields.description: Did engagement lead to reported changes in health care delivery, systems design, or institutional practice?

fields.name: Persuasive Design Techniques
fields.description: Were behavior-change strategies or persuasive technologies mentioned (e.g., nudges, gamification, reminders)?

fields.name: Assess Impact
fields.description: Did the study measure outcomes or success metrics related specifically to engagement efforts?

fields.name: Information
fields.description: Was information provided to patients/public about the study, without involving them in decision-making?

fields.name: Consultation
fields.description: Was patient or public input sought (e.g., through interviews, surveys, focus groups), without involving them in decision-making?
fields.value: Yes - Human intervention to correct and update the model.
fields.evidence_quote: "Afterwards, we started updating the model using human intervention. fields.name: Collaboration
fields.description: Was there shared decision-making or co-design between researchers and participants in any phase of the study?

fields.name: Partnership
fields.description: Were patients/public involved across all stages with formal roles (e.g., co-authors, advisory board, project governance)?

fields.name: Equity or Inclusivity Considerations
fields.description: Did the study aim to include marginalized or underrepresented groups in the engagement process?

fields.name: Ethical, Legal, and Social Implications (ELSI)
fields.description: Did the study address privacy, informed consent, data ethics, or cultural relevance in its engagement or implementation approach?
fields.value: Yes - Study was conducted under a protocol approved by the Providence IRB.
fields.evidence_quote: "This study was conducted under a protocol approved by the Providence IRB (Protocol 2018000188)."

fields.name: Technology Complexity / Integration Readiness
fields.description: Did the study evaluate how complex the technology was or how well it integrated with existing clinical or community workflows?

fields.name: Real-World Evaluation or Deployment
fields.description: Was the technology evaluated or deployed in real-world settings beyond pilot studies or lab prototypes?

fields.name: Feedback and Iterative Adaptation
fields.description: Was feedback from participants used in an ongoing way to adapt the design, strategy, or evaluation?
fields.value: Yes - Model was updated using human intervention.
